Award.AwardTitle: CC*DNI Networking Infrastructure: Enabling Frictionless Scientific Data Transfers in the Texas Medical Center

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Texas Medical Center (TMC) in Houston, Texas, is home to a 15-year networking association called the Collaborative Healthcare Alliance for Technology (CHAT), comprised of 11 research and clinically focused organizations and over 70,000 researchers, educators, students and staff. CHAT is led and operated by the founding member, Baylor College of Medicine (BCM), in support of the community's explosive research-centric, network-intensive needs. This project replaces aging infrastructure with state-of-the-art equipment, while simplifying the design, and simultaneously enabling Â frictionless, high-speed data transfers by creating a first-ever Science DMZ, directly benefiting research labs such as:

- Baylor's Human Genome Sequencing Center, led by Dr. Richard Gibbs, which has transferred hundreds of terabytes of genomic data in the past year, most notably as a part of the CHARGE project;
- the Center for Genome Architecture producing and sharing some 50 Tbytes of new sequenced data each year; and
- the Center for Metagenomics and Microbiome Research engaged in the production and collaborative processing of tens of terabytes of microbial genomic data.

While updating the underlying infrastructure, the project also upgrades the connection between CHAT and its nearest upstream provider, the Southeast Texas GigaPoP (SETG), from 10 to 100 Gbps, matching the recently upgraded 100Gbps connection between SETG and LEARN, the Texas-wide research and education network backbone that ties the R&E community to Internet2. By streamlining research data transfers, the investigators will empower researchers at BCM and other CHAT partners to hasten the eradication of today's greatest health challenges.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project sought to accomplish, and indeed, completed three goals (outcomes). First, the team specified, acquired, configured and implemented the new networking hardware (routers and switches) that replaced the end-of-life CHAT infrastructure, a 20-year Texas Medical Center (TMC)-based cooperative owned and managed by Baylor College of Medicine (BCM) on behalf of 13 TMC affiliates and over 100,000 people. In the process, the infrastructure was simplified from the legacy configuration of six routers, into just three routers, two in Houston (in geo-diverse locations) and one in Dallas. At the same time, the team took advantage of the upgrade process to move one of the existing Houston locations from a leased colo space to a new building owned by BCM, that was more strategically located (especially from a fiber-optic cabling perspective), and far less expensive to operate.

 

The team also upgraded the 10 Gbps(10G)-capable legacy hardware to new 100G-capable equipment, facilitating the upgrade of CHAT’s uplink to the regional R&E aggregator, the SouthEast Texas GigaPoP (SETG). This upgrade extended the 100G path from Internet2 all the way to/through CHAT, thus fulfilling goal/outcome #2.

 

The third and final goal was to instantiate the first-ever CHAT science DMZ. While the proposal was for a 40G-capable environment, technology advancements and market conditions, coupled with extremely aggressive vendor pricing, made it possible for the project to upgrade to a 100G-capable science DMZ. Thus, research labs in the Texas Medical Center (TMC), and specifically the genomics and genetics researchers at BCM, now have access to a 100G science DMZ. BCM Information Technology (IT) is and will continue to work closely with the corporate compliance and security team, along with genomics and genetics research leadership and technical professionals to develop the policies, processes, procedures and workflows to enable the transparent and secure use of the new, high-capacity path to Internet2, now made possible by both the science DMZ and the upgraded CHAT environment. 

 

Finally, it's worth noting that while the team was implementing this project, the BCM Human Genome Sequencing Center (HGSC) was awarded a $505 million contract as a part of the NIH "TopMed" project, which in part requires the near-daily movement of large data sets to collaborating partners across the United States. Thanks to this NSF CC* award, the network infrastructure, and especially the new science DMZ, is now in place to make it possible for the HGSC to fulfill their contractual obligations to move the data sets to/from their partners.
